This reminds me of everytime we hung out in college cafeteria. Reminds me of the time she came over to my place and we baked a cake and watched our favorite show. I'm too shy to send her this song and tell her that this song, to me, is about her. Maybe one day.

Putting a shirt, gym bag, football helmet, a pack of smokes and a lighter, water bottle and his cleats into a box handed to us by the coach. There was a picture with him and his girlfriend, the time we ran into the coach at a carnival on the back wrote "There never seems to be enough time to do the things that you want to do once you find them". Handed the picture to his girlfriend. She read the words to our coach who said "those are lyrics to an old song". After the game (we won) the girlfriend came around. After the post game festivities walking to our cars and someone is playing this on the guitar. Someone stopped and said. This is the song. She said its a sign that he's calling out to us. I didn't feel the moment actually my sister requested The musician play Grave Digger and left after that.   The next week this song was playing during the half time and it made sense. I just saw AJ Croce in concert tonight in Shipshewana IN with my son. We are both big fans of Jim Croce.  AJ is a fine musician, and we enjoyed his concert very much and his own music. I got chills when he sang "Operator" and had tears in my eyes. When I got married in April 1974, my husband and I had chosen Jim Croce's song "Time In A Bottle" for our 1st dance at our reception. I was hoping to hear AJ sing it tonight along with "I'll Have To Tell You I Love You In A Song" but he didn't sing those two favorites of mine but at least I got to hear Operator and a few of Jim's other hits. It was still a great night for me.    AJ, has a new album out now and I wish him all the best success with it and for his career. My son and I really enjoyed AJ's concert tonight and if anyone hasn't seen AJ perform yet I encourage you to do so. He's very entertaining and I loved his stories between songs. He was great and I liked his music and will have to look for his latest album. His father must be beaming with pride when he see's his son tell stories and sing tribute to him looking down from Heaven.  â™¥â™¥

This song is one of my earliest musical memories that I can actually remember. Sitting in a car at a local mall with my brothers waiting for our mother to come out from whatever she had to do (I think it was to get a clock repaired). I was probably 4, maybe early 5 at the most. Even at that very young age, this song was so 'hauntingly beautiful' to me that whenever I hear it, I'm 4 or 5 years old (in 73 or 74), sitting in that station wagon all over again.

There was a man who boarded an aircraft and died.  Generations would spout off what if over and over after his passing.  What if he hadn't died that fateful day.  What if he had recorded more songs.  What if.  The man much like Jim had went in prior to his death and produced his Magnum Opus which was released posthumously and became this man's only #1 song on the Billboard 100.  He was the first to do it and much like Jim who's wife received his honors in 1974, this man had a wife who was very much involved along with his record label in his career.  Both this man's wife and his record label and subsequently the musicians who backed him all said don't release this song.  It's not right for the label.  Willing himself to broaden his sound and having just recovered from surgery due to polyps on his larynx, this man told them he was releasing it and that it would be a hit.  He was right.  Unfortunately there were no touring dates for this song.  This man fondly lost himself recording the song he and his cowriter had jotted down and legend says he was sitting on that dock when he came up with the initial idea for the song.  He whistled his way into history at the end of the song and every time I hear it much like Time in a Bottle, I find myself transported wondering if perhaps Otis is still watching those ships rolling in and out of the harbor.  I don't dwell on what if he had lived. Instead I dwell on thank God he lived long enough to leave this legacy piece of his soul that would touch generations.  Thank God Jim lived to write Time in a Bottle and Thank God Ronnie Van Zant lived long enough to pen Freebird.  Whether you're sitting in the morning sun or you're asking if I could save time in a bottle or telling someone If I leave here tomorrow would you remember me, the feeling of loss we've all felt in our lives is overwhelming.  It cuts us like a diamond, shaping our very souls into chiseled broken works of art.  From here to eternity let us lift up our voices for the time we have is fleeting and before we finish our song it may be gone.  To those who have touched us thank you.  To those who never got to sing may we hear your voice in the sweet by and by.  God Bless and thanks for reading.
